text: Following up on a previous discussion of GHA workflows becoming disabled after 60 days. Does anyone have a solution for keeping them alive? We have quite a few packages which are more-or-less in a maintenance mode currently, and I want to keep the CI alive for them.

elements.text: Following up on a previous discussion of GHA workflows becoming disabled after 60 days. Does anyone have a solution for keeping them alive? We have quite a few packages which are more-or-less in a maintenance mode currently, and I want to keep the CI alive for them.

text: Does triggering another GHA workflow count as activity? I'm wondering if CompatHelper or some other job could make a change to keep it enabled?

elements.text: Does triggering another GHA workflow count as activity? I'm wondering if CompatHelper or some other job could make a change to keep it enabled?

text:
There does not seem to be a definition that I can find for what counts as activity. I would assume a workflow triggering another does not count. And it’s more supposed to be around actual user activity in the repo itself.

In the last thread, I jokingly suggested a script running on Lambda every 60 days loop over all repos, and comment on an issue or open/close one. Which might be a crude way to keep things alive…
